DOC.HEAD: Salvation Army Office Reopens in Time for Christmas
DOC.TEXT: A flood of overnight donations saved the Salvation Army here, which had been swamped by needy families and closed four days before Christmas. ``The outpouring of the public has been marvelous,'' Maj. Robert Pfeiffer, who runs the office, said Friday. Pfeiffer said several thousand dollars had been donated by corporations and individuals after word of the closing spread. On Thursday, Pfeiffer closed his doors because he ran out of money for food and gifts for those in need. Pfeiffer's $80,000 budget, which proved adequate in past years to take the local office from Nov. 1 through Dec. 24, fell short this year because more families than usual needed assistance. The money that came in Thursday night and Friday morning will keep the office afloat, Pfeiffer said. ``We are not turning anyone away,'' Pfeiffer said. ``The Salvation Army is alive and well in New Bedford.'' Pfeiffer blamed recent layoffs of 1,000 workers at various businesses for the increase in needy families. Friday, 400 more were laid off as the Carol Electronic Cables closed, he said. ``The families I was seeing were basically recently unemployed people _ people who didn't have great life savings,'' Pfeiffer said. ``I had people who said `Last year we gave to you, and this year we have to come and take.''' His office usually helps about 1,300 families during the Christmas season. This year, 300 additional families came. On Thursday, Pfeiffer shut down after more than 100 people came to the office seeking help. He offered assistance to those families, but said he could not take anybody else. ``We've gone into using the canned food we had put aside for January and February,'' Pfeiffer said. About half a dozen bell ringers were scattered through New Bedford seeking more money Thursday, Pfeiffer said.
